awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Manipulating Epigenetic Mechanisms to Enhance Non-Viral Transgene Expression
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1404084/1403214
Rege/Elmer

DNA or gene delivery to mammalian cells has several applications in biotechnology and medicine. However, the activation of foreign genes (transgenes), and subsequent efficacy of protein expression from them, is often hindered by defense mechanisms inside the host cell. For example, cells are able to control transgene protein expression by either burying existing genes inside condensed chromosomes in the nucleus in order to turn them off, or by relaxing chromosomes in order to expose genes and activate them. A family of 'epigenetic' enzymes present within cells typically controls these processes of gene regulation; enzymes that activate genes are generally classified as activators, while those that turn genes off are called repressors. In the proposed research, the investigators will study the role of these epigenetic enzymes in regulating the expression from delivered transgenes. Furthermore, tools from the emerging field of synthetic biology will be employed to design novel DNA sequences and activator enzymes that enhance protein expression from delivered transgenes. Findings from these studies will have a transformative impact on biotechnology processes and medical treatments (e.g. gene therapy) that utilize DNA or gene delivery to mammalian cells. Outreach from this project will reach K-12 students through a PCR-based molecular biology project facilitated by the Quanta program at ASU. The proposed outreach will be designed to increase participation of students from underrepresented populations in STEM activities in Arizona and Pennsylvania.

In the same way that words are neatly organized in the pages of books in a library, cellular genes are condensed by histone proteins to form chromosomes in the nucleus. Epigenetic regulation, mediated by several enzymes, plays a key role in controlling gene expression inside cells. Since recent work has shown that epigenetic mechanisms can silence viral genes, it is likely that epigenetics may also regulate the expression of foreign genes (i.e. transgenes) that are delivered in the form of plasmid DNA to mammalian cells. The goal of this project is to manipulate intracellular epigenetic enzymes in order to enhance transgene expression by (1) using drugs to inhibit repressors and to prevent the deactivation of transgenes, (2) adding designed DNA sequences to the plasmids in order to recruit activator enzymes, and (3) using principles from synthetic biology in order to design and validate novel epigenetic activator enzymes that can selectively bind transgenes and enhance their expression. These approaches will deepen our understanding of epigenetic mechanisms that regulate protein expression from foreign transgenes (plasmid DNA) in human cells, leading to increased efficacy of gene therapy treatments in medicine, and cellular engineering approaches in biotechnology.

This award is co-funded by the Biotechnology, Biochemical, and Biomass Engineering Program of the CBET Division and by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.

por.por_cntn:
NSF 1404084: Project Outcomes Report

Background and Significance. Expression from chromosomal DNA is tightly regulated by its interactions with histone proteins. Histone proteins interact with DNA to condense it to different degrees, leading to chromatin structures that range from tight chromatin packing and low gene expression (heterochromatin), to loose chromatin packing and relatively high gene expression (euchromatin). Specific residues of histones can be modified by different enzymes, each of which can affect local DNA-histone interactions and, consequently, gene expression. This epigenetic regulation involves control of gene expression without changing the nucleotide sequence of the target gene. Although these epigenetic interactions are known to regulate the expression levels of chromosomal DNA, these interactions are likely to further affect expression of exogenously delivered genes, such as those encoded on plasmids. The overall goal of this research is to identify and utilize epigenetic targets for enhancing transgene expression, particularly with polymer-mediated delivery of plasmids, for applications in human health and biomanufacturing.  

Intellectual Merit.We employed a parallel screening approach using small-molecule inhibitors of histone-modifying enzymes leading to the identification of several targets that enhance polymer-mediated transgene expression.  Mechanistic studies indicated increased transport of plasmid DNA into the nucleus particularly with HDAC inhibitors. Potential synergy was seen with combinatorial use of some inhibitors, which opens up possibilities for further enhancing transgene expression. We also demonstrated the differential methylation status of plasmids leads to differential transgene expression efficacies. Furthermore, we enhanced gene expression from plasmids after they had become stably integrated into the genome. We designed fusion proteins that increase transcription at epigenetically-repressed transgene inserts. Some of the fusions also enhanced CRISPR editing efficiency at the transgene, which has implications for making cell engineering efforts more efficient and reliable. Over this project period, we have published several papers in peer-reviewed journals with additional manuscripts in different stages of submission and review. 

Broader Impacts: We made several advances in cutting-edge research at the interface of epigenetics, therapeutic delivery and biotechnology. We have trained several doctoral, master?s, undergraduate and high-school students in different topics related to biotechnology and our trainees have gone on to pursue successful careers. We have made significant efforts to recruit and train students from marginalized groups (e.g. African-American, Latino, and female trainees) and have also mentored students from Barrett, the Honors College at ASU and / or the Fulton Undergraduate Research Initiative (FURI). Different aspects related to this project, are included in coursework at ASU. Graduate and undergraduate students in our groups had excellent opportunities to mentor high-school students on different aspects of their research. Graduate students supported by this project were able to gain mentoring experience by advising undergraduates in course credit research and for the International Genetically Engineering Machines Competition (iGEM). Graduate and undergraduate students are included on several of our publications. Overall, we believe that the positive impacts from these activities will be long-lasting as our trainees pursue STEM careers.
